cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
where would the group bacteroids likely be found
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
Bacteroids are a type of bacteria that are commonly found in the human gut, particularly in the intestines. They play a crucial role in the digestion of complex carbohydrates and are part of the normal gut microbiota. Bacteroids are anaerobic, meaning they thrive in environments with little to no oxygen, which is characteristic of the intestinal tract. Additionally, they can also be found in other environments such as soil and the digestive systems of various animals, but their primary association is with the human gastrointestinal system.

Answer:
The group Bacteroids would likely be found in the human gut, particularly in the intestines.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
where would the group bacteroids likely be found
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Bacteroidetes are not limited to gut microbiota, they colonize a variety of habitats on Earth. For example, "Bacteroidetes", together with "Proteobacteria, Firmicutes" and "Actinobacteria", are also among the most abundant bacterial groups in rhizosphere. They have been detected in soil samples from various locations, including cultivated fields, greenhouse soils and unexploited areas. "Bacteroidetes" also inhabit freshwater lakes, rivers, as well as oceans. They are increasingly recognized as an important compartment of the bacterioplankton in marine environments, especially in pelagic oceans. Halophilic "Bacteroidetes" genus "Salinibacter" inhabit hypersaline environments such as salt-saturated brines in hypersaline lakes. "Salinibacter"\xa0 shares many properties with halophilic "Archaea" such as "Halobacterium" and "Haloquadratum" that inhabit the same environments. Phenotypically, "Salinibacter" is remarkably similar to "Halobacterium" and therefore for a long time remained unidentified.\n', 'Lacertoids have a wide geographic distribution. The Lacertidae are found throughout Europe and Asia, with a major radiation endemic to Africa. The Teiidae are diverse in South America, but some members of the group occur in southern North America as well. The Amphisbaenia are especially widespread, occurring in North America, Europe, Africa, South America, and the Caribbean. The origins of the group are unclear. The oldest definitive lacertoid is the amphisbaenian "Plesiorhineura", from the early Paleocene of North America. Given that it resembles modern worm lizards, the lacertoids most likely appeared and diversified in the Cretaceous.\n', 'The roseobacter clade is mostly found in the marine environment. The various species of roseobacter each have their own ecological niche. Several isolates have been captured from a vast number of ecosystems in coastal areas and open oceans. Roseobacters are a significant part of bacterial communities connected to phytoplankton, macroalgae, and several marine animals. Different lifestyles such as mutualistic and pathogenic have been proposed. Members of the clade are spread all over temperate and polar oceans, and are also considerable in sea ice ecosystems. They are suggested to be extensive within coastal sediments, deep pelagic ocean, and deep sea sediments. The roseobacter clade has immense diversity of metabolic proficiency and regulatory circuits, which can be credited to their prosperity in a vast number of marine ecosystems.\n', 'Fossils of the Danubitoidea have been found in the Triassic of Afghanistan, Russia, China, Papua New Guinea; Italy, Switzerland, Hungary; British Columbia, Yukon, Nunavut; Idaho, Nevada, and California.\n', 'Coleophora dubiella is a moth of the family Coleophoridae. It is found in Algeria, Libya, Morocco, Tunisia, Spain, France, southern Russia and Turkey.\n', 'were ultimately the ancestors of ammonoids and coleoids, and had appeared by the Floian. It is widely held that the Bactritida, a Silurian–Triassic group of orthocones, are paraphyletic to the coleoids and ammonoids – that is, the latter groups arose from within the Bactritida. An increase in the diversity of the coleoids and ammonoids is observed around the start of the Devonian period, and corresponds with a profound increase in fish diversity. This could represent the origin of the two derived groups.\n', 'In 2010, there was a discovery of two species that belong to this group of tapeworms to have infected bivalve mollusks in South Carolina. Lab samples were taken from this event in 200 clams which were measured and necropsied. Following the test, two species of tapeworm plerocercoids ("Duplicibothrium" spp) and merocercoids ("Rhodobothrium" spp) were observed. The plerocercoids occupied the digestive gland ducts and merocercoids were found beneath the mantle of the "Molinia lateralis", the clams from S. Carolina.\n', 'BULLET::::- Mellor, R.B.: Bacteroids in the Rhizobium-legume symbiosis inhabit a plant internal lytic compartment: Implications for other microbial endosymbioses. J Exp. Bot., 40, 831-839 (1989)\n', 'Eudendrium racemosum is a marine species of cnidaria, a hydroid (Hydrozoa) in the family Eudendriidae. It was described by Cavolini in 1785. Hydroids are one of the most abundant organisms in hard-substratum benthic communities, more specifically in temperate seas, such as the Mediterranean. Similar to most modular organisms, they have high growth rates. In fact, "E racemosum" has been frequently found in northeastern Spain, specifically in Medes Islands, showing a maximum population density in summer with a minimal density during the winter (this is when it typically exists as dormant stolon). Their rapid growth coupled with their ability to store the necessary material to survive the winter is due to their efficient feeding and digestive methods.\n', 'Members of the Gammaproteobacteria and Flaviobacteria classes were also shown to be abundant within the ice matrix, and thus to be adapted to the sea ice conditions. Genera of the Gammaproteobacteria class found in the Ross Sea and around the Antarctic waters include Colwellia, Marionomonas, Pseudoalteromonas and Psychrobacter. The orders Chlamydiales and Verrucomicrobiales were also found in the sea ice microbial assemblage of these locations. The predominance of Gammaproteobacteria in sea ice around the globe have been reported by many studies. A large proportion of the identified SIMCO in these studies were shown to belong to phylotypes associated with heterotrophic taxa\n']

'Bacteroidetes' also inhabit freshwater lakes, rivers, as well as oceans."
   - **Role**: This passage highlights the ecological versatility of Bacteroidetes, indicating that they are found in diverse environments beyond the human gut, including soil and aquatic ecosystems. This information is crucial for understanding their ecological roles in nutrient cycling and their interactions with other organisms in these habitats.

2. **Marine Environments**:
   - **Passage 1**: "They are increasingly recognized as an important compartment of the bacterioplankton in marine environments, especially in pelagic oceans."
   - **Role**: This emphasizes the importance of Bacteroidetes in marine ecosystems, particularly as part of the bacterioplankton community. Their presence in the ocean suggests they play a significant role in marine food webs and biogeochemical cycles.

3. **Hypersaline Environments**:
   - **Passage 1**: "Halophilic 'Bacteroidetes' genus 'Salinibacter' inhabit hypersaline environments such as salt-saturated brines in hypersaline lakes."
   - **Role**: The mention of halophilic Bacteroidetes indicates their adaptability to extreme environments, which broadens the understanding of their ecological niches. This adaptability is significant for studying microbial life in extreme conditions.

4. **Soil Microbiota**:
   - **Passage 1**: "For example, 'Bacteroidetes', together with 'Proteobacteria, Firmicutes' and 'Actinobacteria', are also among the most abundant bacterial groups in rhizosphere."
   - **Role**: This information connects Bacteroidetes to plant health and soil fertility, as they are part of the rhizosphere microbiome, which is crucial for nutrient uptake and plant growth.

### Conclusion:
The extracted content provides a comprehensive overview of the habitats where Bacteroidetes are likely to be found, including soil, freshwater, and marine environments, as well as extreme hypersaline conditions. This knowledge is essential for understanding their ecological roles, interactions with other microorganisms, and contributions to nutrient cycling in various ecosystems. By recognizing the diverse habitats of Bacteroidetes, we can appreciate their significance in both terrestrial and aquatic environments, as well as their potential applications in biotechnology and environmental management.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine where the group Bacteroidetes (often referred to as "bacteroids") is likely to be found, we need to consider their ecological niches and the environments they inhabit. While Bacteroidetes are well-known for their presence in the human gut, their distribution is much broader.

1. **Gut Microbiota**:
   - Bacteroidetes are indeed a significant component of the human gut microbiota, particularly in the intestines, where they aid in the digestion of complex carbohydrates and contribute to overall gut health. Their anaerobic nature allows them to thrive in the low-oxygen environment of the intestines.

2. **Soil Environments**:
   - Beyond the gut, Bacteroidetes are found in various soil environments, including cultivated fields, greenhouse soils, and unexploited areas. They play a crucial role in soil health and nutrient cycling, interacting with plant roots and other soil microorganisms.

3. **Aquatic Ecosystems**:
   - Bacteroidetes are also prevalent in freshwater and marine environments. They are recognized as an important component of the bacterioplankton in oceans, contributing to marine food webs and biogeochemical cycles. Their presence in these ecosystems highlights their ecological versatility.

4. **Extreme Environments**:
   - Certain genera of Bacteroidetes, such as Salinibacter, are adapted to hypersaline environments, such as salt-saturated brines in hypersaline lakes. This adaptability to extreme conditions showcases their ecological diversity.

5. **Rhizosphere**:
   - In addition to their roles in soil and aquatic environments, Bacteroidetes are abundant in the rhizosphere, the region of soil directly influenced by plant roots. They contribute to plant health by enhancing nutrient uptake and promoting beneficial interactions with plants.

### Conclusion:
The group Bacteroidetes is likely to be found in a variety of environments, including the human gut, various soil types, freshwater and marine ecosystems, and even extreme hypersaline conditions. Their ecological roles are diverse, ranging from aiding digestion in humans to contributing to soil health and marine biogeochemical processes.

### Answer:
The group Bacteroidetes would likely be found in the human gut, particularly in the intestines, as well as in various soil environments, freshwater lakes, rivers, and marine ecosystems. They can also inhabit extreme environments, such as hypersaline lakes, and are significant components of the rhizosphere, contributing to plant health and nutrient cycling.

- **Soil** (in agricultural and natural settings),
- **Freshwater bodies** (such as lakes and rivers),
- **Marine ecosystems** (including coastal areas and deep-sea environments),

Their ecological roles in nutrient cycling and organic matter decomposition further emphasize their importance in both terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems. The adaptability of Bacteroidetes to various habitats illustrates their ecological versatility and significance in maintaining ecosystem health. Hydroids are one of the most abundant organisms in hard-substratum benthic communities, more specifically in temperate seas, such as the Mediterranean. Similar to most modular organisms, they have high growth rates. In fact, "E racemosum" has been frequently found in northeastern Spain, specifically in Medes Islands, showing a maximum population density in summer with a minimal density during the winter (this is when it typically exists as dormant stolon). Their rapid growth coupled with their ability to store the necessary material to survive the winter is due to their efficient feeding and digestive methods.
', 'Members of the Gammaproteobacteria and Flaviobacteria classes were also shown to be abundant within the ice matrix, and thus to be adapted to the sea ice conditions. Genera of the Gammaproteobacteria class found in the Ross Sea and around the Antarctic waters include Colwellia, Marionomonas, Pseudoalteromonas and Psychrobacter. The orders Chlamydiales and Verrucomicrobiales were also found in the sea ice microbial assemblage of these locations. The predominance of Gammaproteobacteria in sea ice around the globe have been reported by many studies. A large proportion of the identified SIMCO in these studies were shown to belong to phylotypes associated with heterotrophic taxa
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To address the question of where the group Bacteroidetes (often referred to as bacteroids) is likely to be found, we can extract relevant information from the provided passages. The first passage contains the most pertinent details regarding the habitats of Bacteroidetes. Here’s a consolidation of the relevant information:

### Extracted Information:
1. **Diverse Habitats**: Bacteroidetes are not limited to gut microbiota; they colonize various habitats on Earth.
2. **Soil Presence**: They are abundant in the rhizosphere and have been detected in soil samples from cultivated fields, greenhouse soils, and unexploited areas.
3. **Aquatic Environments**: Bacteroidetes inhabit freshwater lakes, rivers, and oceans, and are recognized as an important component of bacterioplankton in marine environments, particularly in pelagic oceans.
4. **Hypersaline Environments**: The genus Salinibacter, a member of Bacteroidetes, is found in hypersaline environments such as salt-saturated brines in hypersaline lakes.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Ecological Niches**: By recognizing that Bacteroidetes can thrive in diverse environments (soil, freshwater, marine, and hypersaline), the model can better infer the ecological roles and interactions of these bacteria. This understanding can lead to improved predictions about their behavior and functions in different ecosystems.

2. **Linking Environmental Conditions to Microbial Presence**: The information about specific habitats (e.g., rhizosphere, bacterioplankton) allows the model to draw causal connections between environmental conditions and the presence of Bacteroidetes. For instance, it can reason that nutrient availability in soil or organic matter in aquatic environments may influence the abundance of these bacteria.

3. **Adaptation Mechanisms**: The mention of Salinibacter in hypersaline environments suggests that Bacteroidetes have adapted mechanisms to survive extreme conditions. This can enhance the model's ability to infer how microbial communities might respond to environmental stressors, such as salinity changes or nutrient fluctuations.

4. **Broader Implications for Microbial Ecology**: Understanding where Bacteroidetes are found can lead to broader inferences about microbial ecology, such as the roles these bacteria play in nutrient cycling, symbiotic relationships with plants, and their contributions to ecosystem health.

5. **Predictive Modeling**: With this consolidated knowledge, the model can improve its predictive capabilities regarding the distribution of Bacteroidetes based on environmental factors, which can be crucial for applications in agriculture, environmental monitoring, and microbiome research.

In summary, the extracted information about the habitats of Bacteroidetes enhances the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities by providing a framework for understanding ecological interactions, environmental adaptations, and the implications of microbial presence in various ecosystems. This knowledge can be leveraged to make informed predictions and inferences about microbial behavior and community dynamics.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.

Additionally, they can also be found in other environments such as soil and the digestive systems of various animals, but their primary association is with the human gastrointestinal system.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
where would the group bacteroids likely be found
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Bacteroidetes are not limited to gut microbiota, they colonize a variety of habitats on Earth. For example, "Bacteroidetes", together with "Proteobacteria, Firmicutes" and "Actinobacteria", are also among the most abundant bacterial groups in rhizosphere. They have been detected in soil samples from various locations, including cultivated fields, greenhouse soils and unexploited areas. "Bacteroidetes" also inhabit freshwater lakes, rivers, as well as oceans. They are increasingly recognized as an important compartment of the bacterioplankton in marine environments, especially in pelagic oceans. Halophilic "Bacteroidetes" genus "Salinibacter" inhabit hypersaline environments such as salt-saturated brines in hypersaline lakes. "Salinibacter"\xa0 shares many properties with halophilic "Archaea" such as "Halobacterium" and "Haloquadratum" that inhabit the same environments. Phenotypically, "Salinibacter" is remarkably similar to "Halobacterium" and therefore for a long time remained unidentified.\n', 'Lacertoids have a wide geographic distribution. The Lacertidae are found throughout Europe and Asia, with a major radiation endemic to Africa. The Teiidae are diverse in South America, but some members of the group occur in southern North America as well. The Amphisbaenia are especially widespread, occurring in North America, Europe, Africa, South America, and the Caribbean. The origins of the group are unclear. The oldest definitive lacertoid is the amphisbaenian "Plesiorhineura", from the early Paleocene of North America. Given that it resembles modern worm lizards, the lacertoids most likely appeared and diversified in the Cretaceous.\n', 'The roseobacter clade is mostly found in the marine environment. The various species of roseobacter each have their own ecological niche. Several isolates have been captured from a vast number of ecosystems in coastal areas and open oceans. Roseobacters are a significant part of bacterial communities connected to phytoplankton, macroalgae, and several marine animals. Different lifestyles such as mutualistic and pathogenic have been proposed. Members of the clade are spread all over temperate and polar oceans, and are also considerable in sea ice ecosystems. They are suggested to be extensive within coastal sediments, deep pelagic ocean, and deep sea sediments. The roseobacter clade has immense diversity of metabolic proficiency and regulatory circuits, which can be credited to their prosperity in a vast number of marine ecosystems.\n', 'Fossils of the Danubitoidea have been found in the Triassic of Afghanistan, Russia, China, Papua New Guinea; Italy, Switzerland, Hungary; British Columbia, Yukon, Nunavut; Idaho, Nevada, and California.\n', 'Coleophora dubiella is a moth of the family Coleophoridae. It is found in Algeria, Libya, Morocco, Tunisia, Spain, France, southern Russia and Turkey.\n', 'were ultimately the ancestors of ammonoids and coleoids, and had appeared by the Floian. It is widely held that the Bactritida, a Silurian–Triassic group of orthocones, are paraphyletic to the coleoids and ammonoids – that is, the latter groups arose from within the Bactritida. An increase in the diversity of the coleoids and ammonoids is observed around the start of the Devonian period, and corresponds with a profound increase in fish diversity. This could represent the origin of the two derived groups.\n', 'In 2010, there was a discovery of two species that belong to this group of tapeworms to have infected bivalve mollusks in South Carolina. Lab samples were taken from this event in 200 clams which were measured and necropsied. Following the test, two species of tapeworm plerocercoids ("Duplicibothrium" spp) and merocercoids ("Rhodobothrium" spp) were observed. The plerocercoids occupied the digestive gland ducts and merocercoids were found beneath the mantle of the "Molinia lateralis", the clams from S. Carolina.\n', 'BULLET::::- Mellor, R.B.: Bacteroids in the Rhizobium-legume symbiosis inhabit a plant internal lytic compartment: Implications for other microbial endosymbioses. J Exp. Bot., 40, 831-839 (1989)\n', 'Eudendrium racemosum is a marine species of cnidaria, a hydroid (Hydrozoa) in the family Eudendriidae. It was described by Cavolini in 1785. Hydroids are one of the most abundant organisms in hard-substratum benthic communities, more specifically in temperate seas, such as the Mediterranean. Similar to most modular organisms, they have high growth rates. In fact, "E racemosum" has been frequently found in northeastern Spain, specifically in Medes Islands, showing a maximum population density in summer with a minimal density during the winter (this is when it typically exists as dormant stolon). Their rapid growth coupled with their ability to store the necessary material to survive the winter is due to their efficient feeding and digestive methods.\n', 'Members of the Gammaproteobacteria and Flaviobacteria classes were also shown to be abundant within the ice matrix, and thus to be adapted to the sea ice conditions. Genera of the Gammaproteobacteria class found in the Ross Sea and around the Antarctic waters include Colwellia, Marionomonas, Pseudoalteromonas and Psychrobacter. **Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

The initial reasoning process correctly identifies that Bacteroids (or Bacteroidetes) are primarily associated with the human gut, particularly in the intestines, where they play a vital role in the digestion of complex carbohydrates. However, it overlooks the broader ecological diversity and habitats where Bacteroidetes can be found, as highlighted in the retrieved passages.

To enhance the reasoning process, we should incorporate the following points from the retrieved knowledge:

1. **Habitat Diversity**: Bacteroidetes are not limited to the human gut but are found in various environments, including:
   - **Soil**: They colonize cultivated fields, greenhouse soils, and unexploited areas.
   - **Freshwater**: They inhabit freshwater lakes and rivers.
   - **Marine Environments**: They are significant components of bacterioplankton in marine ecosystems, especially in pelagic oceans.
   - **Hypersaline Environments**: Certain genera, such as Salinibacter, thrive in hypersaline conditions, such as salt-saturated brines.

**Answer:**
The group Bacteroids (Bacteroidetes) would likely be found not only in the human gut, particularly in the intestines, but also in a variety of other environments. They inhabit soil, including cultivated fields and greenhouse soils, as well as freshwater lakes and rivers. Additionally, Bacteroidetes are significant components of marine ecosystems, especially in pelagic oceans, and some genera, such as Salinibacter, are found in hypersaline environments like salt-saturated brines. This diversity highlights their ecological importance beyond just being gut inhabitants.

question_info.question: where would the group bacteroids likely be found
passages:
Bacteroidetes are not limited to gut microbiota, they colonize a variety of habitats on Earth. For example, "Bacteroidetes", together with "Proteobacteria, Firmicutes" and "Actinobacteria", are also among the most abundant bacterial groups in rhizosphere. They have been detected in soil samples from various locations, including cultivated fields, greenhouse soils and unexploited areas. "Bacteroidetes" also inhabit freshwater lakes, rivers, as well as oceans. They are increasingly recognized as an important compartment of the bacterioplankton in marine environments, especially in pelagic oceans. Halophilic "Bacteroidetes" genus "Salinibacter" inhabit hypersaline environments such as salt-saturated brines in hypersaline lakes. "Salinibacter"  shares many properties with halophilic "Archaea" such as "Halobacterium" and "Haloquadratum" that inhabit the same environments. Phenotypically, "Salinibacter" is remarkably similar to "Halobacterium" and therefore for a long time remained unidentified.
Lacertoids have a wide geographic distribution. The Lacertidae are found throughout Europe and Asia, with a major radiation endemic to Africa. The Teiidae are diverse in South America, but some members of the group occur in southern North America as well. The Amphisbaenia are especially widespread, occurring in North America, Europe, Africa, South America, and the Caribbean. The origins of the group are unclear. The oldest definitive lacertoid is the amphisbaenian "Plesiorhineura", from the early Paleocene of North America. Given that it resembles modern worm lizards, the lacertoids most likely appeared and diversified in the Cretaceous.
The roseobacter clade is mostly found in the marine environment. The various species of roseobacter each have their own ecological niche. Several isolates have been captured from a vast number of ecosystems in coastal areas and open oceans. Roseobacters are a significant part of bacterial communities connected to phytoplankton, macroalgae, and several marine animals. Different lifestyles such as mutualistic and pathogenic have been proposed. Members of the clade are spread all over temperate and polar oceans, and are also considerable in sea ice ecosystems. They are suggested to be extensive within coastal sediments, deep pelagic ocean, and deep sea sediments. The roseobacter clade has immense diversity of metabolic proficiency and regulatory circuits, which can be credited to their prosperity in a vast number of marine ecosystems.
Fossils of the Danubitoidea have been found in the Triassic of Afghanistan, Russia, China, Papua New Guinea; Italy, Switzerland, Hungary; British Columbia, Yukon, Nunavut; Idaho, Nevada, and California.
Coleophora dubiella is a moth of the family Coleophoridae. It is found in Algeria, Libya, Morocco, Tunisia, Spain, France, southern Russia and Turkey.
were ultimately the ancestors of ammonoids and coleoids, and had appeared by the Floian. It is widely held that the Bactritida, a Silurian–Triassic group of orthocones, are paraphyletic to the coleoids and ammonoids – that is, the latter groups arose from within the Bactritida. An increase in the diversity of the coleoids and ammonoids is observed around the start of the Devonian period, and corresponds with a profound increase in fish diversity. This could represent the origin of the two derived groups.
In 2010, there was a discovery of two species that belong to this group of tapeworms to have infected bivalve mollusks in South Carolina. Lab samples were taken from this event in 200 clams which were measured and necropsied. Following the test, two species of tapeworm plerocercoids ("Duplicibothrium" spp) and merocercoids ("Rhodobothrium" spp) were observed. The plerocercoids occupied the digestive gland ducts and merocercoids were found beneath the mantle of the "Molinia lateralis", the clams from S. Carolina.
BULLET::::- Mellor, R.B.: Bacteroids in the Rhizobium-legume symbiosis inhabit a plant internal lytic compartment: Implications for other microbial endosymbioses. J Exp. Bot., 40, 831-839 (1989)
Eudendrium racemosum is a marine species of cnidaria, a hydroid (Hydrozoa) in the family Eudendriidae. It was described by Cavolini in 1785. Hydroids are one of the most abundant organisms in hard-substratum benthic communities, more specifically in temperate seas, such as the Mediterranean. Similar to most modular organisms, they have high growth rates. In fact, "E racemosum" has been frequently found in northeastern Spain, specifically in Medes Islands, showing a maximum population density in summer with a minimal density during the winter (this is when it typically exists as dormant stolon). Their rapid growth coupled with their ability to store the necessary material to survive the winter is due to their efficient feeding and digestive methods.
Members of the Gammaproteobacteria and Flaviobacteria classes were also shown to be abundant within the ice matrix, and thus to be adapted to the sea ice conditions. Genera of the Gammaproteobacteria class found in the Ross Sea and around the Antarctic waters include Colwellia, Marionomonas, Pseudoalteromonas and Psychrobacter. The orders Chlamydiales and Verrucomicrobiales were also found in the sea ice microbial assemblage of these locations. The predominance of Gammaproteobacteria in sea ice around the globe have been reported by many studies. A large proportion of the identified SIMCO in these studies were shown to belong to phylotypes associated with heterotrophic taxa
